column4: rmatted. I tried to create a new partition but then it sai it needed to create a new disklabel, which I said was ok. After a while an error dialog came up saying  "Error while setting new disklabel."  After Gparted failed I went into the terminal and did some fdisking. I first formatted the entire thing, but that failed saying "The partition table has been altered!
Calling ioctl() to re-read partition table.
WARNING: Re-reading the partition table failed with error 16: Device or resource busy.
The kernel still uses the old table.
The new table will be used at the next reboot.
17 heads, 59 sectors/track, 1020 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 1003 * 512 = 513536 bytes
Disk identifier: 0x77277eae
Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
the floodbot was being serious
chances are that the drive is faulty, which the fact it took several minutes before it gave you an error strongly hints to (as well as the fact that it stopped working in windows)
and there'd probably be no way of getting around that then?
if the damage was on the part of the drive that holds the partition table, unlikely
that's probably the case, it's a shame too, it was one of those GBA flash cards
is there currently any important data on it?
no, no important data, However, one interesting thing is that the manager for the GBA does boot up, leading me to believe that the "OS" of the card is on an entirely different physcal part.
that's possibly, i've really no idea how the GBA would manage its stuff...
if you do what genii said, though, you'll also lose that
That is assuming that the "OS" is on that same physical drive. My theory is that I can't even read the section that contains the OS, It's a rather simple OS.
the GBA OS itself is most likely in the internal ROM
